From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Another New Paper:  Multiagent HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=g0-lwovkq220KuXLDwJ05BqPexZxD6A1Uyyr03ZKz3hr9jn5SNgl7rlX8G0
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

David, good work on the paper. I love multi-agents and seeing your videos
was fun indeed. 

> Mattias, you're pretty spot on with your characterization of method
> 1a.  Just to be clear though, the actual r(x) function tells the CPPN
> where it is within an agent, while it is the actual x value that
> allows for role differentiation. 
>
> As for method 1b, I actually tired it while doing preliminary
> experiments for the paper.  The results were not quite as good as the
> r(x) method, which is why we chose to pursue r(x).  The reason for
> difference is that in the r(x) method, the x means both position
> within the team and position within the world.  HyperNEAT can exploit
> this by relating agent position in the team to agent position in the
> world.  For example agents on the left need to turn right to reach the
> center, and vice versa.  Using method 1b decouples the idea of team
> position and world position, so it is more difficult, but not
> impossible, for HyperNEAT to make these kind of discoveries.

Excellent, that answers that question then. And your explanation makes sense.

> I am curious about method 2, it does seem a bit like "naming" the
> agents which has shown to be useful in multiagent scenarios.  It is a
> bit more than that as the names have real meanings and are not
> arbitrarily assigned.   I would imagine, for HyperNEAT at least, that
> it would be more difficult to find global patterns across agents with
> method 2, since the CPPN does not have access to that geometric
> information.

I'm pretty certain that HyperNEAT could use the information in method 2 to
evolve networks that solve the problem, but I'd guess it would be slower,
but without specific tests, it would be hard to know. 

Thanks for your feedback,
mattias
